caseTitle: SYLVANUS JUXON-SMITH v. K.L.M. ROYAL DUTCH AIRLINES
summary: In this civil appeal from the Accra Fast Track High Court, Sylvanus Juxon-Smith sued K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines for being denied boarding despite holding a valid business class ticket, claiming $600,000 in damages for losing a lucrative contract in Brussels. The Court of Appeal upheld the finding of deliberate denial of carriage but set aside the damages award. It held that while the airline breached its contract, the claimed loss was too remote as there was no evidence that a trip to Brussels was in the contemplation of the parties when the ticket was purchased. The court excluded Exhibits A–E and G for failing to comply with Section 161 of the Evidence Decree regarding authentication of foreign official documents. Exhibit F, a magazine issue, was properly admitted. The plaintiff failed to provide credible evidence of a submitted bid or efforts to notify Brussels authorities, rendering the damages unprovable and excessive.
verdict: Appeal allowed in part; damages and costs set aside due to lack of evidence on remoteness and failure to meet burden of proof.
winningSide: Defendant/Appellant (K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines) on the issue of damages
rationaleHighlights: Exhibits A–E and G excluded for non-compliance with s. 161 NRCD 323 requiring authentication of foreign official documents
Exhibit F (magazine) properly admitted under Rule 156
Damages awarded for breach of carriage contract but set aside due to remoteness and lack of proof of Brussels contract bid
Plaintiff failed to prove that Brussels trip was in contemplation of parties at contract formation
Trial judge's award deemed excessive and against weight of evidence
